div1.p: Luckett requests that Sandy visit the Lucketts as Staunton schools "must be in a state of disorganization & must remain so during the war." He also discusses relations with England.

I wrote you some two or three months ago and as there were two or three letters sent off at the same time, to neither of which any answer has been recived I think it more than probable that none of them reached their destination. They were sent to our office during our rainy spell & as our mails frequently came up more or less and by the sudden showers, it is likely the letters shared at that time the same fate but werte & they were srcully thrown away by our Mail boy--who sometimes played us other tricks by his negligence.

In my letter I conveyed a wish from all the family & particularly from Henry that you would permit Sandy to pay us a visit and uitie our family school for the winter & spring, as your schools must be in a state of disorganization & and must remain so during the war--a rendence nither us too at this parune would impress his
health quietly besides the advantage of trar it to our that has led to domertre a life as he. We have an excellent Teacher--a Virginian but a little too much of the Puritan order in the thinking of his rules &c such as rising at day break and an occasional confiniment in May house for very minor dificiences, but I will to him dffny any saturday that they may enjoy thier Horses & to their hearts desire.

We have piest had the tiding, of Englands demand for the restoration of our Captured ministers, which has more to others than to me--I would rather she would have told us a fire iron clad war streamer with Armstrong guns & as have whipped the Scoundrels ourselves. Our People here are very much at a loss to account for madness & folly on their part as to a quarrel with England at this time, for judging from their acts there never was a people so & crazy since the world was made. But there may be method in their madness--Like Macbeth they may --I am in blood slipped in so far, returning, now as hard as to
go over
They may themselves on the brink of whipped they certainly are, and unable to stand the outside nature& fear of discovery of the lies and they have so long practiced on their of victors & won of sin parts opened that the now haunts their imagination & to dark them from the Truth, get up a war with England--dont you believe Cameron was telling an enormous lie when he made out his report of 6 or 700,000 men in arms. I doubt whether they have or had over 350000 in the fold of arms--I doubt too whether they ever got 150000000 loan from the Banks. They are to me with Gulf Stream that takes its at the Cape of St. Rogue the North American coast the climate of western Europe & scarcely mingles with any other water--They have
the man Conquest a separate & distant we with such of that they never cropped out before in the lives of Cromwell-as haters of other people but masked their motive as lay as they could fatten on our tobacco sugar & cotton crops by high Tariffs & fishing counties--but when like the copper smith they find their craft in danger they show themselves in their their
caracter--the Hirarado of the Chinese, the ferocity of the , with his cowardice & lying of the Gipsy
my Eyes devl , I hope to read of their buring town, smoking ruins & devastated fields.

I fow now the mor will be too short--I want the whole South to imitate Carthagenian who swore his children on his coutries altar eternal hate to the vile wretches. They have learned one lesson and Europe too, that our peculiar institution that they hoped was our weakness, is a lever of strength, We of the better rejoiceful that subject more than you of Virginia, Tennessee or Kentucky--that their wishes & expectations been realized, can the mind of man conceive the awful horror of a , the midnight conflagration & the stagnation of innocence. Had they succeded, if alive, no doubt I should with my other, now have a coporal with a on my family, like my bale of cotton nor , to pay for the of our Subjugation--
I of Everett in in this & there on that, his Electioneering speech of 1860 & his 4th of July address that the gallaries is the fate of Lincoln Sewared Cameron Bates & the Blairs
It is very late & cold, & if you can read this it is more than I can do. Our kindest regards to Mrs. S & the children all.
